pullRequest.body:
This PR is a forward port of mathlib3 PR !3#18863

Co-authored-by: Heather Macbeth <25316162+hrmacbeth@users.noreply.github.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Oh sorry, I had somehow missed the fact that this is a forward-port :facepalm: I'll delete some of my comments, the ones left should still be applicable.
I think you are supposed to change the headers of the ported files to match the mathlib3 commit. See [this wiki page](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/wiki/Mathlib3-Synchronisation)

> 

Oh I see; I thought that was just for new files being moved, not files that were already ported but are now being modified. I tried clicking the link, but didn't follow which of that applied to this port? Which headers need to change, all of them?

Those of all files modified by your PR, yes. To find the right header, you should look on the [out-of-sync page](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib-port-status/out-of-sync) and click on the file you are porting. Then the left column shows the changes in mathlib3 since the last synchronization. When you hover over he change you are porting, it highlights the corresponding change in the middle column (which is the output of mathport), and looking at the corresponding diff tells you what to change.

> Those of all files modified by your PR, yes. To find the right header, you should look on the [out-of-sync page](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib-port-status/out-of-sync) and click on the file you are porting. Then the left column shows the changes in mathlib3 since the last synchronization. When you hover over he change you are porting, it highlights the corresponding change in the middle column (which is the output of mathport), and looking at the corresponding diff tells you what to change.

Done, thanks!

🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

> Whichever maintainer is reading this? Should we keep on adding the `#align`s? If so, please **do note merge this**.

We should be keeping the aligns, because otherwise there wasn't much point merging the mathlib3 version.
@jcommelin, I take it that's a statement that `#align`s don't matter any more?

bors r-

(I think Johan's merge was in response to a maintainer merge comment that Yael deleted?)
Canceled.

> > Whichever maintainer is reading this? Should we keep on adding the `#align`s? If so, please **do note merge this**.
> 
> We should be keeping the aligns, because otherwise there wasn't much point merging the mathlib3 version.

I thought the main point of merging things into mathlib 3 at this point was to take advantage of mathport?
bors merge

This is exactly [MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable.mono'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/StronglyMeasurable/Basic.html#MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable.mono') right?
Yes, thanks! Deleted and updated.

```suggestion
    [SecondCountableTopology (G ⧸ Γ)] (K : PositiveCompacts (G ⧸ Γ)) [Subgroup.Normal Γ]
```

```suggestion
    (K : PositiveCompacts (G ⧸ Γ)) [Subgroup.Normal Γ] [μ.IsHaarMeasure]
```

```suggestion
    · refine (AEStronglyMeasurable.mono' hg ?_).comp_measurable meas_π
```

```suggestion
    · refine (AEStronglyMeasurable.mono' hg ?_).comp_measurable meas_π
```

```suggestion
```
what happens with `@[to_additive]` automatically here? should this be a bug report?
I think there are just too many things going on at once for `@[to_additive]` to work out which things should be additivized and which should remain the same...
indentation is wrong here
sorry can you please tell me what's wrong? I don't see. Thanks!
Ok I think I've got it.

The indentation level of the type (aka statement) has changed with the switch to Lean 4.
The convention is now to indent by 4 spaces on a new line after the `:`.
If the statement is short, you can of course still write it on the same line as the `:` with only 1 space in between.
indentation is wrong here.
Here too - what should the right indentation be?
can you replace all `Type _` in the PR with `Type*`?

```suggestion
    ∫⁻ x, f x ∂μ = ∑' g : G, ∫⁻ x in s, f (g • x) ∂μ := 
  (lintegral_eq_tsum' h f).trans ((Equiv.inv G).tsum_eq (fun g ↦ ∫⁻ (x : α) in s, f (g • x) ∂μ))
```

```suggestion
    QuotientAddGroup.automorphize ((g ∘ (@Quotient.mk' _ (_))) • f)
      = g • (QuotientAddGroup.automorphize f : G ⧸ Γ → M) :=
  AddAction.automorphize_smul_left f g
```

```suggestion
    ∫⁻ x, f x ∂μ = ∑' g : G, ∫⁻ x in s, f (g • x) ∂μ :=
```
